body: After years of negotiation, a final division of the four boroughs outside Manhattan among six cable television companies was approved yesterday by the Board of Estimate. Officials said service could be brought into some homes as early as June. ''In Staten Island,'' said Morris Tarshis, director of franchises, ''it could come like that'' and he
title: DELAYED YEARS, CABLE TV TO EXPAND TO ALL OF CITY

body: The six cable-television companies that were awarded rights to wire the boroughs outside of Manhattan under an agreement concluded yesterday are variously owned by large communications concerns and small local ventures. Manhattan has been served for more than a decade by Manhattan Cable TV in the southern portion and Teleprompter in the northern
title: LARGE AND SMALL COMPANIES AMONG THE WINNERS OF CABLE CONTRACTS

body: Negotiators for New York City tried yesterday to resolve a year-old dispute involving the city's cable television negotiations by reshuffling the areas assigned to two of the companies in line for cable franchise awards. But one of the companies - Cable-vision Systems New York City - said the proposed reorganization was unacceptable. The city, in
title: CABLEVISION REJECTS PROPOSAL BY CITY TO SWAP SOME AREAS

body: Susan Beth Goldstein, daughter of Mrs. Gertrude W. Goldstein of New York and the late Dr. Eli Goldstein, was married yesterday to Martin Kenneth Goldstein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Goldstein of Monsey, N.J. Rabbi David Kahane of the Sutton Place Synagogue performed the ceremony at the Helmsley Palace Hotel. The bride is a lecturer in the
title: SUSAN GOLDSTEIN WED TO MARTIN K. GOLDSTEIN

body: Almost a year behind schedule, a new City Council is preparing to take office tomorrow with some old problems still facing it. The local legislature's election was delayed a year because the Federal Government objected to the Council's initial reapportionment lines. Certification of its election was delayed another month by a recount of a
title: NEW CITY COUNCIL WILL TAKE OFFICE

body: The nursery at Bay Ridge High School in Brooklyn looks much like any other. The walls are a sunny yellow and the children's names and ages are printed on brightly colored construction paper and tacked to the walls. A 16-month-old girl begins to cry when a 25-month-old takes away her toy. Calley Bittel, the early-childhood teacher, talks quietly to
title: 2 HIGH SCHOOLS AIDING STUDENTS WITH CHILDREN

body: THERE is nothing circuitous about Flatbush Avenue. It cuts a long and almost direct swath through thec enter of Brooklyn from the Manhattan Bridge to the Belt Parkway. A long the way, it passes neighborhoods that have been in flux for d ecades. Change in neighborhoods and change in regional shopping patterns lead to evolution in the commercial life
title: FLATBUSH AVENUE TAKES ON NEW IDENTITY

body: Many years ago, the Seamen's Church Institute would send small boats out into New York City's harbor to pick up sailors and bring them to their building for social events. It was a fact universally acknowledged that sailors on shore were likely to be plied with liquor by those women known as ladies of the night, and that they would then be robbed.
title: ABOUT NEW YORK

body: A 16-year-old Brooklyn youth was shot and critically wounded last night for no apparent reason as he stood with friends on a Coney Island street corner, the police said. The victim, Lenny Lamagna, of 2009 72d Street in the Bay Ridge section, was shot once in the head at 8:30 P.M. at the intersection of West 37th Street and Neptune Avenue, the
title: YOUTH IS WOUNDED IN CONEY I.

body: The apparent defeat in Tuesday's voting of Angelo J. Arculeo, the only Republican holding a district seat in the New York City Council, has left Democrats in control of all 35 district seats. Mr. Arculeo, the Council minority leader, lost to Sal F. Albanese, a 33-year-old Democrat, in Brooklyn's 31st District, according to unofficial figures. With
title: DEMOCRATS GAIN SEAT ON CITY COUNCIL

body: Angelo J. Arculeo of Brooklyn, the minority leader of the City Council and the only Republican to hold a district seat, was trailing in a close race in yesterday's voting. Mr. Arculeo, who has represented the 31st District, centered in Bay Ridge, for more than 20 years, was trailing Sal F. Albanese, a Democrat and 33-year-old high school teacher
title: CITY COUNCIL MINORITY LEADER TRAILING IN CLOSE RACE; REFERENDUM WINNING

body: Representative John LeBoutillier, Republican of Westbury, L.I., considered one of the most conservative members of the House of Representatives, was defeated yesterday by a Democratic Suffolk County legislator, Robert J. Mrazek of Centerport. With 84 percent of the vote counted in the Third Congressional District, Mr. Mrazek was leading by 10,000
title: ON L.I., MRAZEK SCORES A VICTORY OVER INCUMBENT

body: Daniel Patrick Moynihan won a second term yesterday with the biggest majority in a Senate race in New York history, piling up a total that makes him the fifth United States Senator to win reelection by a million-vote margin. Mr. Moynihan, a Democrat-Liberal who had once worried about a challenge from the Democratic left, defeated Assemblywoman
title: MOYNIHAN WINS OVERWHELMING VICTORY

body: Halloween was marked with caution and restraint yesterday as thousands of families in the New York metropolitan area chose costume contests, parades and private parties over trick or treating. With about 50 incidents of contaminated candy, cakes or soda reported in the past few days in the region, many parents sought to curb the traditional
title: CAUTION CAN'T MASK HOLIDAY'S TRUE FACE: HALLOWEEN'S A PARTY

body: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan yesterday waved in the air a ''ballot card'' that asked Republican contributors if they would like Social Security to be ''voluntary.'' ''It is an outrage,'' he said. Not only did Republicans ''terrify'' people by suggesting this, said Mr. Moynihan, the Democratic-Liberal candidate for United States Senator from New
title: MOYNIHAN ASSAILS G.O.P. FUND 'BALLOT'

body: Assemblywoman Florence M. Sullivan, the Republican, Conservative and Right to Life candidate for the United States Senate from New York, today accused her Democratic-Liberal opponent, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, of ''straddling the fence'' on the death penalty. In her first campaign swing through Long Island since the September primary, the
title: MRS. SULLIVAN ATTACKS MOYNIHAN ON DEATH PENALTY

body: In the one-room 1840 white-frame former schoolhouse on his property where he does his writing, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan delivered a professorial lecture on defense policy today. Frowning, he read off charges that his Republican, Conservative and Right to Life opponent for the United States Senate from New York, Assemblywoman Florence M.
title: MRS. SULLIVAN'S CHARGES REBUTTED BY MOYNIHAN

body: Voters will select 35 district members for the City Council next week, but only a handful of the incumbents have challengers strong enough to threaten them, according to Council and city officials. There will be new faces on the Council, though, because two incumbents did not seek re-election, and three others lost in last month's Democratic
title: FEW SURPRISES EXPECTED IN CITY COUNCIL ELECTIONS

body: WHAT is the perfect way to watch the New York Marathon? To run in it, surely - a privilege that will be denied all but 16,000 of the more than two million people who will turn out on Sunday to be part of it. The lucky entrants will see some authentic New York curiosities: Fort Wadsworth at dawn, for one, the Staten Island gathering point for
title: TIPS FOR MARATHON FANS

body: Assemblywoman Florence M. Sullivan's campaign for United States Senator from New York ran short of money yesterday. ''We've gone off television,'' said her campaign manager, Rob Ryan. ''We'll wait until the weekend for the national campaign committee to study poll results. Then we'll await their decision.'' Mrs. Sullivan has spent $225,000, almost
title: SULLIVAN SENATE CAMPAIGN REPORTS IT IS SHORT OF FUNDS

body: Representative Leo C. Zeferetti strode down Fourth Avenue in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn the other day, getting a wave and good wishes from a passing motorist every few steps. The four-term Brooklyn Democrat returned the greetings and continued south into a blustery wind, the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge looming in the distance. This was his home
title: 2 IN HOUSE BATTLE FOR THE SAME SEAT

body: Florence M. Sullivan, who is challenging Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan in his bid for re-election, today criticized the National Republican Senate Committee, contending it was withholding contributions from her campaign. The Washington-based committee, which helps Republican candidates in Senate races around the nation, ''has been slow in getting
title: MRS. SULLIVAN ASSAILS A REPUBLICAN PANEL OVER DELAY IN FUNDS

body: Economic issues - local, national and international - dominated the campaign for United States Senate from New York today as the two major-party candidates made their separate ways through the western part of the state. Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, running for re-election on the Democratic and Liberal lines, said in a speech here that the
title: U.S. SENATE CAMPAIGN FOCUSING ON ECONOMY

body: Florence M. Sullivan, the Republican candidate for Senator from New York, said yesterday that the United States should not withdraw from the United Nations if that organization bars Israel. At a news conference in Albany, the Mrs. Sullivan, who is also the candidate of the Conservative and Right to Life Parties, endorsed the Reagan Administration's
title: U.S. SHOULD REMAIN IN U.N., G.O.P. SENATE HOPEFUL SAYS

body: The major-party candidates for the United States Senate, Florence M. Sullivan and Daniel Patrick Moynihan, disagreed strongly about the state of the economy and legislation on abortion and birth control, in a debate held here today. Senator Moynihan, running for re-election as the Democratic and Liberal candidate, said the economy was in ''very bad
title: NEW YORK'S SENATE HOPEFULS SPLIT ON ECONOMY IN DEBATE

body: The major candidates for United States Senator from New York argued over defense spending yesterday and accused each other of being unfair in discussing it. Politely but persistently, an animated Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan demanded numbers and definitions from his opponent, Assemblywoman, Florence M. Sullivan. Hurriedly looking through a heap
title: MRS. SULLIVAN AND MOYNIHAN TRADE CHARGES; Excerpts from debate, page B5.

body: With just over three weeks until the Congressional elections, attention focuses on television blitzes, the unemployment rate and the relative quality of get-out-the-vote operations. But a process completed months ago has already done much to shape the House delegations for the 98th Congress. Before ballots were printed and filing fees paid, state
title: REDISTRICTING PITS SOME VERY STRANGE BEDFELLOWS

body: Two entourages pushed successively south along Broad Street in the downtown financial district yesterday. Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan led the first and was greeted like a celebrity and, in some cases, like an old friend as he campaigned for a second term as a Democrat-Liberal. Assemblywoman Florence M. Sullivan, his Republican, Conservative and
title: MOYNIHAN AND MRS. SULLIVAN CAMPAIGN IN FINANCIAL DISTRICT

body: New York City officials hope to divert $88 million from the construction of a new sewage plant so they can repair two crumbling treatment plants in Brooklyn that now threaten to release raw sewage into surrounding waters. Last month the city said it was scaling down plans for the North River plant on Manhattan's Upper West Side, thereby saving $240
title: NEW YORK ACTS TO END THREAT OF SEWAGE SPILL

body: A Brooklyn motorist towing a neighbor's disabled van on the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway was killed and the neighbor seriously injured early yesterday when another car crashed into them after they stopped to secure their towline, the police reported. The driver of the third vehicle was also seriously hurt. The accident occurred at 5:40 A.M. just
title: Motorist Fixing Towline On Expressway Is Killed

body: The morning after she won the Republican nomination for United States Senate, Assemblywoman Florence M. Sullivan of Brooklyn declared that the basic issue of her campaign would be the record of her Democratic opponent, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan. ''People believe he is invincible,'' she said. ''I don't know where they get that idea. I'm in
title: MRS. SULLIVAN ATTACKING MOYNIHAN AS TOO LIBERAL

body: The Port of New York, once unchallenged as the premier shipping center of the nation, is scrambling to maintain its dominance as a regional port and is even gaining somewhat in the fierce competition for the lucrative North Atlantic trade. ''Twenty-five years ago, this was still the port of the nation,'' said Peter C. Goldmark Jr., executive
title: NO. 1 NO MORE, NEW YORK PORT SEEKS TO STRENGTHEN ITS ROLE

body: A visual feast will unfold in New York Harbor tomorrow as a fleet of some 200 yachts, the largest turnout in the nine-year history of the Governor's Cup race, crosses the starting line off the Battery beginning at 11 A.M. Unlike most yacht races, which take place well offshore and out of sight, this 16-mile competition takes the fleet through the
title: THE BIG YACHT RACE THAT EVERYONE CAN SEE

body: Florence M. Sullivan, a little-known State Assemblywoman from Brooklyn, won the Republican nomination for the United States Senate last night, and Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, as expected, easily won the Democratic nomination. With more than 90 percent of the votes counted, Mrs. Sullivan was 11 percentage points ahead of her rivals. She had 41
title: STATE LEGISLATOR IS SENATE CHOICE

body: With march music thundering from a tape recorder in the background, Whitney North Seymour Jr. solemnly shook hands with hundreds of commuters the other day as they bounded onto trains at the Croton-Harmon station in Westchester County. But despite a flag-bedecked van, cheery red campaign balloons and a sign that said, ''Meet Your Next U.S.
title: G.O.P. SENATE HOPEFULS IN A RACE FOR RECOGNITION

body: EARLY last week, a delegation of five tenants from a three-building c omplex on St. Johns Place in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn wenti nto a local office of the Department of Housing Preservation and D evelopment to meet their new landlord: New York City. Their 50-unit complex was seized on Aug. 13 by the city in the first phase of a
title: NEW LAW REDUCES BROOKLYN TAX FORECLOSURES

body: A 16-year-old Brooklyn youth was killed and another was injured yesterday when a gun that they were handling went off, the police said. The slain youth was identified as Joseph Cumming. The incident occurred at 3:30 P.M. as the other youth, Hector Hernandez, was handing the gun to Mr. Cumming on 63d Street between Second and Third Avenues in the
title: Youth Killed and a 2d Injured As Gun Goes Off in Brooklyn

body: CLOSELY WATCHED CONTESTS FOR HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES, REGION BY REGION By RICHARD L. MADDEN In the nine Northestern states, pinched by recession and redistricting, the fight to shape the 98th Congress is focusing on at least 15 close races for the House. Two years ago, with Ronald Reagan leading the ticket, the Republicans picked up 10 House seats
title: THE EAST

body: A man who kept the police at bay for 10 hours on Thursday in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn by threatening to detonate what he said were a hand grenade and a bomb was in custody yesterday pending his arraignment today in Criminal Court in Brooklyn. The police said that the grenade was a practice model that contained no explosives and that the
title: THE CITY; Man With 'Bomb' Awaits Arraigning

body: Never Mind Degrees From a working-class boyhood in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn to Brooklyn College and on to ''beat'' Greenwich Village in the 50's and a Westbeth studio for the last 12 years -Gilbert Sorrentino has been a compleat New York poet, novelist and book reviewer. Critics have described his dozen-plus volumes as comedic,
title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY

body: For Democrats, this year's elections represent a chance to establish almost unshakable control over the State Assembly. For Republicans, the Assembly elections will be a fight for survival. The Democrats have controlled the Assembly since the 1974 elections following the Watergate scandals. To the surprise of many Republicans - and some Democrats -
title: STATE ASSEMBLY'S DEMOCRATS TRY TO DOMINATE, AS REPUBLICANS TRY TO SURVIVE

body: Remember the Brooklyns Vandals have stripped the former Navy armory in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn of just about anything valuable, even the copper sheathing on the roof. But a pair of relics mounted on the wall were too heavy for them to cart off - parts of the masts from two historic destroyers, the first and second U.S.S. Brooklyn. The
title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY

body: BAY RIDGE is an enclave of churches, children and quiet streets on t he western edge of Brooklyn, where the view of New York Bay is a lmost as spectacular as the pale blue Verrazano-Narrows Bridge that l ooms above it. Residents of this tightly woven community of 116,000 think of it as a small town. Many of them can walk down their streets and know
title: BAY RIDGE

body: A Brooklyn man charged with mailing his mother an explosive device that killed her was freed on bail yesterday. The suspect - Craig Kipp, 28 years old - was released in Federal District Court in Brooklyn on $300,000 bail secured by his father, Howard Kipp. The sone is scheduled to reappear in court on Aug. 27. Judge Charles Sifton examined
title: BAIL FOR MAN IN KILLING OF MOTHER

body: Detectives looking into the recent murders of five women found strangled in lower Manhattan and Brooklyn believe that no one killer was responsible in all cases, according to investigators. The investigators indicated that detectives made sufficient progress in the last week, in at least one case, to support that conclusion. However, police
title: POLICE DOUBTFUL OF SINGLE KILLER IN 5 STRANGLINGS

body: Stephen J. Crowley, former president of the Detectives Endowment Association of the New York City Police Department, died Monday at Lutheran Medical Center in Brooklyn. He was 63 years old and lived in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn. Mr. Crowley served as president of the association, the collective-bargaining agent for the 4,000 detectives on
title: STEPHEN J. CROWLEY, EX-HEAD OF DETECTIVES GROUP, IS DEAD

body: Taste is largely a matter of habit, and for almost four generations of Brooklynites, preferences for cakes, pies and pastries were to a large extent shaped by the buttery miracles turned out by the Ebinger Baking Company. By the time that family-run chain went bankrupt in 1972, there were 67 bright and gleaming Ebinger's bakeshops in Brooklyn,
title: DE GUSTIBUS; A BROOKLYN BAKERY ADDS NEW LUSTER TO EBINGER'S NAME

body: Bucking the Mainstream A ssemblywoman Florence M. Sullivan of Brooklyn, the most conservative of three candidates for the Republican nomination to run against Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, concedes that she may be ''a little outside the Reagan mainstream'' in her enthusiasm for the Federal student loan program. At the age of 52, Mrs. Sullivan is
title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY

body: The findings of a handwriting expert and of a dog trained in tracking human scents helped lead to the arrest of a Brooklyn man charged with killing his mother by mailing her an explosive device in a hollowed-out cookbook, investigators revealed yesterday. They said that the German shepherd dog had found that the suspect's scent, as sniffed in one
title: DOG HELPED POLICE SEIZE SON IN MOTHER'S SLAYING

body: Dozens of detectives and other investigators are working virtually round the clock to analyze physical evidence and to trace the movements of five women killed in an unusual series of strangulations in lower Manhattan and Brooklyn. While some detectives sought to identify the latest victim, whose unclothed body was found Tuesday in the Narrows off
title: POLICE CONDUCT INTENSE SEARCH IN 5 STRANGLINGS

body: A Brooklyn man was arrested last night and charged with the May 7 mail-bomb murder of his mother, city and Federal authorities said. The suspect, 28-year-old Craig Kipp, was arrested by postal inspectors and city detectives at 11 P.M. outside his Bay Ridge home, at 28 Marive Avenue, according to authorities. A short time later, Mr. Kipp, was booked
title: SON IS ARRESTED IN BOMB DEATH OF HIS MOTHER

body: Dozens of New York City detectives intensified their efforts yesterday to solve the recent murder by strangulation of five women in Brooklyn and Manhattan. The latest victim, still unidentified yesterday, was found Tuesday in New York Bay off the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn. Four of the murders have occurred in the last three weeks. The first was
title: FIVE STRANGLINGS OF CITY WOMEN PUZZLING POLICE

body: The nude body of a young woman who had been sexually assaulted, beaten and strangled was found floating off the 69th Street Pier in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn yesterday. An electrical cord was tied around her neck and lashed around her hands behind her. It was the fourth known murder by strangulation of a woman in the city in less than three
title: WOMAN, KILLED BY STRANGLING, FOUND OFF PIER

body: A Brooklyn teen-ager being held on a rape charge hanged himself Saturday night in the holding pen of a precinct stationhouse with shoelaces from his sneakers, the police said. The teen-ager, 19-year-old Kevin Kuperman of 5995 Shore Parkway in the borough's Bay Ridge section, was discovered at 7:50 P.M. Saturday by a desk sergeant in the 69th
title: Rape Suspect Hangs Himself In Precinct Stationhouse Cell

body: A 25-year-old Brooklyn man was arrested last night and charged as one of the men who killed two guards during a $40,000 payroll robbery on July 22 in the Bay Ridge section of the borough, the police said. The suspect, Pedro Lopez, of 157 17th Street, near the Park Slope section of Brooklyn, was arrested in East New York at 10:30 P.M. by homicide
title: THE CITY; 2d Suspect Seized In Payroll Slayings

body: Brooklyn detectives yesterday arrested one of the men suspected in the killing of two guards during a $40,000 payroll robbery on Thursday in the Bay Ridge section of the borough, the police said. The suspect, 27-year-old Ricardo Diaz of 713 Third Avenue, was arrested after a night of questioning by detectives, said Capt. John Ricci of the 68th
title: THE CITY; Suspect Arrested In Payroll Deaths

body: The police said yesterday that they knew the identities of three men suspected of killing two guards during a $40,000 payroll robbery Thursday in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn. Heavily armed detectives hunted the three men, who were described as ''locals,'' and Deputy Inspector Charles V. Rorke of the Brooklyn Detective Area said, ''We have
title: POLICE SAY THEY KNOW 3 IN PAYROLL GUARDS' MURDER

body: Two guards delivering a payroll were shot and killed in Brooklyn yesterday afternoon on a private Bay Ridge industrial street by gunmen who escaped with $40,000. A third guard, Ed Percoco, obeyed the holdup men's order to ''hit the ground'' and was unhurt. Shaken, he said later that he had worked just five months for the delivery company -Payroll
title: 2 PAYROLL GUARDS KILLED IN A BROOKLYN ROBBERY

body: It has been the invisible campaign so far - the contest for the Republican nomination to oppose Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, a Democrat. None of the three Republicans -Whitney North Seymour Jr., Muriel Siebert and Florence M. Sullivan - had planned to run until the disclosure that Bruce F. Caputo, who was to be the Republican candidate, had
title: IN NEW YORK, AN INVISIBLE G.O.P. RACE

body: With the New York State political map changed to reflect population losses and to cut the Congressional delegation by five seats, three significant primary election fights have begun to take shape. In one, two members of the House of Representatives from Syracuse plan to run against each other. The two other contests are in Brooklyn, where the maps
title: NEW YORK DISTRICTING BRINGS 3 MAJOR PRIMARIES FOR HOUSE

body: The New York City Health Department has released the names of 17 food establishments it said had violated the Health Code. The department also released the names of two establishments that reopened after correcting earlier violations and two that were closed for failure to do so. The establishments are: VIOLATIONS Govas Restaurant, 94 1/2 Greenwich
title: 17 FOOD ESTABLISHMENTS CITED FOR VIOLATIONS OF HEALTH CODE

body: A Brooklyn discotheque whose intended purchaser was shot to death early Sunday is being investigated by the State Liquor Authority for possible hidden ownership, Alan Cohen, the authority's senior investigator, disclosed yesterday. He also said the premises had a history of illegal gambling operations. The would-be buyer, Frank Fiala, a millionaire
title: DISCO IN SLAYING IS SUBJECT OF INQUIRY

body: With private maneuvers to reduce the four-candidate field for Governor, and balloons, buttons and a splash of wall posters, Republicans converged on the city yesterday for what their chairman called ''the most wide-open convention in Republican history in New York State.'' Each candidate for Governor - Paul J. Curran, James L. Emery, Lewis E.
title: G.O.P. GATHERS FOR 'WIDE OPEN' STATE CONVENTION

body: A plan by a Federal court master to revise New York's political boundaries - scrambling districts and pitting incumbents against each other - was made public yesterday. Drawn as an alternative to lines voted by the State Legislature, the plan will be weighed tomorrow by three Federal judges. ''If the Justice Department approves the Legislature's
title: COURT GETS MASTER'S DISTRICTING PLAN

body: Describing herself as the only candidate with a chance of getting three lines on the ballot, Assemblywoman Florence M. Sullivan said yesterday that she would run for United States Senator from New York. Mrs. Sullivan, a Republican who represents the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn, said she was closer to the Republican mainstream than either of the
title: STATE LEGISLATOR FROM BROOKLYN IN BID FOR SENATE

body: Anne Albergo Fairchild looked for a wedding dress at Saks Fifth Avenue, and one in beaded white lace, at $2,000, was her preference. Then she went to I. Kleinfeld & Son in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, and bought one like it for $800 less. The 22-year-old secretary, who was married to Keith Fairchild, a telephone installer, on May 22, had saved up $10,000
title: RECESSION? NOT FOR WEDDINGS

body: With enthusiasm, desperation and little regard for the elements, New Yorkers scattered to the outer territories for the Memorial Day weekend, kicking off the summer season on beaches, in parks and in vacation cottages. Under skies that stayed overcast and drizzly for much of the weekend, they left by the thousands, while those who were left behind
title: WEATHER OR NOT, MANY FLEE CITY FOR WEEKEND

body: The Justice Department yesterday appointed Edward A. McDonald, a career prosecutor, to be the new chief of its Brooklyn-based Organized Crime Strike Force for the Eastern District of New York, the unit that spearheaded the Abscam investigation into political corruption. The 35-year-old Mr. McDonald, currently an assistant chief of the unit,
title: PROSECUTOR IS NAMED IN BROOKLYN

body: The American Craft Museum at 44 West 53d Street is celebrating its 25th anniversary by giving birth - to an American Craft Museum II, in the lobby of International Paper Plaza, 77 West 45th Street. It has opened three exhibitions - one at the new museum, two at the old -to mark the rebirth of papermaking by hand in the United States. At the new
title: WEEKENDER GUIDE; Friday; BIRTH OF A MUSEUM

body: A young man running across a highway in Brooklyn was struck and killed by a police car chasing a speeder, the police said. The two officers in the patrol car were slightly injured by flying glass when the man's body was hurled into the windshield of the speeding patrol car on the Belt Parkway near 83d Street at about 11:45 P.M. Monday. Sgt. John
title: THE CITY; Police Car Kills Brooklyn Man, 18

body: To be sure, there are more poetic and celebrated harbingers of spring than the pungent odor of hot tar or the hiss of steaming asphalt meeting cool pavement. But New York drivers welcome the highway maintenance crews that have now taken to the streets again to tend the winter's crop of potholes. Early last month, just as the Bureau of Highway
title: RITE OF SPRING IS HELD WITH HOT TAR AND ASPHALT

body: The New York State Legislature approved a new set of political maps for itself this evening amid threats by the Assembly Republicans and some Senate Democrats that they would go to court to keep the plan from going into effect. The plan, which reapportioned state Senate and Assembly districts, passed the Democrat-controlled Assembly, 92 to 57, with
title: LEGISLATORS APPROVE PLAN TO REMAP THEIR DISTRICTS

body: After months of infighting, the Legislature's Democratic and Republican leaders said today that they had reached agreement on a reapportionment plan that will eliminate five Congressional seats and endanger some Democratic State Senators and Republican Assemblymen. Bipartisan bills with the new Congressional and Legislative district lines are
title: DISTRICTING PLAN DRAWN IN ALBANY; SOME INCUMBENTS MAY LOSE SEATS

body: An incendiary device that exploded and killed a Brooklyn woman on Friday contained a note that made threats against other members of her family, the police said yesterday. They also said they had determined that the device, a hollowed-out cookbook, had been mailed from Staten Island. Detective Stephen Gardell said the note - written on the inside
title: DEVICE THAT KILLED BROOKLYN WOMAN HELD THREATS TO FAMILY

body: A 54-year-old Board of Education supervisor was fatally wounded in her Brooklyn home yesterday afternoon when she opened a parcel containing an elaborate bomb inside a hollowed-out cookbook, the police reported. They said that when the woman, Joan Kipp of 132 91st Street in the Bay Ridge section, opened the package, which had arrived by mail, there
title: BROOKLYN WOMAN KILLED BY BOMB MAILED INSIDE HOLLOWED-OUT BOMB

body: The unrelated deaths of two children last month were ruled homicides yesterday, and three adults were charged, the police said. The New York City Medical Examiner's office said both children had been beaten. The first case involved 3-year-old Tony King, who died March 2 at Long Island College Hospital in Brooklyn shortly after his mother brought
title: Deaths of Two Children Are Termed Homicides

body: The Berkeley Institute, a 97-year-old private school in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn, will merge next fall with the Carroll Street School, a 15-year-old elementary school just a few blocks away. The merged coeducational school, which will be known as the Berkeley-Carroll Street School, will start with nursery school and go through the 12th
title: TWO BROOKLYN PRIVATE SCHOOLS TO MERGE IN THE FALL

body: Ted Weiss does not want to go to Queens. Olga A. Mendez does not want to leave Roosevelt Island. Thomas J. Bartosiewicz says, ''I kind of like Staten Island, but ...'' But Mr. Bartosiewicz would kind of like to continue representing the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn in the State Senate and not have to search for new, farflung constituents, as is
title: REDISTRICTING WORRYING NEW YORK LAWMAKERS

body: A labor-Liberal Party-minority coalition, similar to an alliance attempted in last year's mayoral election, is shaping up for Lieut. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and against Mayor Koch in the Democratic gubernatorial primary. Last year's effort failed to come up with a strong challenger against the Mayor, and the coalition collapsed. Many labor unions were
title: New York Political Notes; CUOMO GAINING BACKING OF ANTI-KOCH COALITION

body: ''I hear all sorts of people saying, 'To think I voted for Reagan,' '' said James M. Seidelman, a 37-year-old union pipefitter at the Oldsmobile plant in Lansing, Mich. ''Well, I'm one of them. ''I used to have the feeling that when things got in trouble, Republicans could fix them. But I guess I was wrong. If things keep going like they are, four
title: BLUE-COLLAR WORKERS' SUPPORT FOR REAGAN DECLINES

body: A redrawing of New York City's political map in which Manhattan's ''silk stocking'' Congressional District would be totally unraveled was proposed yesterday by Democrats. Replacing the district would be one starting on East 79th Street, crossing Central Park and ascending the West Side into the Bronx, then wandering eastward to Co-Op City. Once
title: PLAN BY DEMOCRATS EFFACES OLD 'SILK STOCKING' DISTRICT

body: While the advertising community was still reeling from J. Walter Thompson's disclosure on Tuesday that an estimated $18 million of nonexistent revenues had been logged into an agency computer, the company announced yesterday that its accountants and lawyers had uncovered an additional $6.5 million that was recorded in the fourth quarter of last
title: THOMPSON FINDS NEW IRREGULARITY

body: At least 12 firemen were temporarily disabled yesterday by fumes while fighting a small fire in a factory on the former site of the Fort Hamilton Army base in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn, the authorities said. Firemen began coughing, showing signs of dizziness and complaining of headaches shortly after 6:46 P.M., when they arrived to fight
title: FUMES DISABLE 12 FIREFIGHTERS

body: Problems with feeder cables left 2,100 Consolidated Edison customers in Brooklyn and Queens without electricity for about an hour last night, a spokesman for the utility said. The spokesman, Virginia McLaughlin, said the first loss of power began at 7:17 P.M., when trouble developed in a feeder cable in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn. About 700
title: BRIEF POWER LOSS AFFECTS 2,100

body: Paul Theroux, whose latest novel, ''Mosquito Coast,'' will be published next month, lives in London. By Paul Theroux New Yorkers say some terrible things about the subway - that they hate it, or are scared stiff of it, or that it deserves to go broke. ''I haven't been down there in years,'' is a common enough remark from a city dweller. Even people
title: SUBWAY ODYSSEY

body: At first glance, Brooklyn's south-western shore would seem an unlikely place for residential development. It has suffered from years of decline and neglect and is cut off from Bensonhurst and Bay Ridge, two of its closest neighborhoods, by the Belt Parkway. But two local developers, who share an affinity for waterfront living, have chosen a
title: ABOUT REAL ESTATE; A LUXURY CONDOMINIUM ALONG BROOKLYN WATERFRONT

body: CAREY REPORTED SET TO ANNOUNCE HE WILL NOT RUN ALBANY, Friday, Jan. 15 (By RICHARD J. MEISLIN, Spec ial to the New York Times) - Governor Carey will announce today that he has decided not to seek a third term in office, members of his family and top aides said last night. ''He's not running,'' said one of the Governor's senior aides in a telephone
title: No Headline

body: Change comes slowly to Brooklyn's Bay Ridge section, a sleepy, old residential community along the shore facing Staten Island over the Narrows and New York Bay. Yet there are subtle signs of transformation in a neighborhood most noted for its panoramic views of the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge and one of the oldest military bases in the country, Fort
title: IN BAY RIDGE, DEMAND SPURS BUILDING
